sub_topic: Precision measurements of the weak interaction
message_1: "What is the probability of a top quark decaying to a W boson and a bottom quark in a proton-proton collision at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) with a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV, based on precise measurements of the weak interaction?"
message_2:
The probability of a top quark decaying to a W boson and a bottom quark is determined by the branching ratio of this decay mode. In the Standard Model of particle physics, top quarks decay almost exclusively to a W boson and a bottom quark, with a branching ratio of nearly 100%.

However, the probability of producing a top quark in a proton-proton collision at the LHC with a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV is a separate question. This probability depends on the parton distribution functions (PDFs) of the colliding protons and the cross-section for top quark production.

The cross-section for top quark pair production (ttbar) at 13 TeV is about 800 picobarns (pb). The cross-section for single top quark production is lower, with the t-channel process having a cross-section of about 150 pb, the s-channel process having a cross-section of about 10 pb, and the tW-associated production having a cross-section of about 50 pb.

To calculate the probability of producing a top quark in a proton-proton collision at the LHC, we can add the cross-sections for all these processes and divide by the total inelastic proton-proton cross-section at 13 TeV, which is about 70 millibarns (mb).

Probability = (800 pb + 150 pb + 10 pb + 50 pb) / 70,000 pb â‰ˆ 0.0143 or 1.43%

So, the probability of producing a top quark in a proton-proton collision at the LHC with a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV is about 1.43%. Since the branching ratio for the top quark to decay to a W boson and a bottom quark is nearly 100%, the probability of this specific decay occurring in a proton-proton collision at the LHC is also approximately 1.43%.
